mods.abstract: STOLEN, NEGRO AND MULE. On Saturday [illegible] the 9th inst., from the undersigned, [illegible] man of black complexion, 32 years of [illegible] about 150 pounds; 5 feet 9 inches high [illegible] when spoken to, holds his head to the side and looks you straight in the face; the mule is MOUSE COLORED, a mare, 8 years old, 13 1/2 hands high, branded indistinctly on the left shoulder with the letter D. There were two men seen with the negro at my place six miles east of Minden, on the road to Monroe riding a black and a roan horse, and I believe they took him and the mule off, he had on the pants he had worked in all the week, but had a clean shirt by no coat. For the property and theives I will pay a reward of One Thousand Dollars if delievered at my house, or if lodged in jail, where I can get them, Eight Hundred Dollars, or fFive Hundred for the negro and mule. R. K. Burnett. Shreveport papers copy 1 time and send to Goodwill. july13-1t
mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections ( http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special )
mods.accessCondition: E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments about the collection.

Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain. Permission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Department, Louisiana State University Libraries.
mods.note: Louisiana Runaway Slave Advertisements, 1836-1865, Louisiana Digital Library, Baton Rouge, La.
